javaslang

Interface Kind<TYPE extends Kind<TYPE,?>,T>

  • Type Parameters:
    TYPE - container type
    T - component type
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Arbitrary<T>, FilterMonadic<M,T>, Gen<T>, IndexedSeq<T>, LinearSeq<T>, List<T>, Match.MatchMonad<R>, Option<T>, Seq<T>, Set<T>, Stack<T>, Stream<T>, Traversable<T>, Traversable.IterableKind<T>, Try<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Either.LeftProjection, Either.RightProjection, Failure, Lazy, List.AbstractList, List.Cons, List.Nil, Match.MatchMonad.Otherwise, Match.MatchMonad.When.Then, None, Queue, Some, Stream.AbstractStream, Stream.Cons, Stream.Nil, Success

    public interface Kind<TYPE extends Kind<TYPE,?>,T>
    A Kind is the type of a type constructor.

    It is denoted as decomposition of a type constructor, i.e. List<T> is Kind<List<?>, T>.

    Higher-kinded/higher-order types cannot be expressed with Java. This is an approximation, it has its limitations.

    Examples:

    Limitations:

    • Once a type extends Kind with a concrete first generic parameter type, like List does, the Kind is fixated. There is no way for subclasses to implement a more specific Kind.

    See also

    • Generics of a Higher Kind (Moors, Piessens, Odersky)
    • Kind (type theory) (wikipedia)
    • Type constructor (wikipedia)
    Since:
    2.0.0
